editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SPIGHTFUL SISTER. A New Comedy. Written by Abraham Bailey, of Lincolns-Inn, Gent.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Dring the Younger, at the White Lion next Chancery-Lane, in Fleet-Street, 1667.

EPiſtles and Prologues being for the moſt part skipt over without reading, I had thought to have ſilenc'd my Pen as to either of them both, had not the importunity of the Stationer (who was unwilling to have a blank page, but that the Buyer might have enough for his money) prevailed with me ſo far as to give thee this ſhort account of it; That as it is a Play, ſo I made the writing thereof onely my Recreation, not my Study; done in few hours and youthful years, that may (rightly conſider'd) excuſe the Faults therein, which (if I am not partial) are not great, nor many; onely theſe few committed by the negligence or overſight of the Printer: I muſt deſire thee either gently to paſs over, or elſe with thy Pen to correct.

PAge 3. line 20. the comma at weary, and for steps read ſleeps. p. 4. l. 19. for warrant 1. torrent. l. 31. for a fable r. affable. p. 5 l 2. for ſurprize r. ſuppreſs. l 27. for come r. can p. 7. l 31 for time r. line. p. 12. l. 32 r. Kidnappers. p. 14. l. 6. r. expoſtulate. p. 16. l. 15. r. what p 18. l. 31 r. ſollicited. p. 26. l. 17. r. favour. p 35. l 17. r. Occus. p. 47. l. 12. r. Beucer. p. 62. l. 23. r. you.

list.item: Petus. A young Lord, afterwards Berania's Sweet-Heart.
Lidorus. A Lord, Friend to Petus.

item.hi: King, Chancellour, Clowns, Watchmen, Conſtables, Gods, Goddeſſes, Nymphs, Servants, Murtherers.

list.item: Loſana. The Spightful Siſter to Berania.
Sarah. An old Sweet-Heart to Beucer.

div.head: Books Printed for Thomas Dring Junior, at the White Lion in Fleet-Street, where you may be furniſht with moſt ſorts of Playes.
div.p: A General Hiſtory of the Caribby Iſlands, being an exact Deſcription of all the Engliſh Plantations, &c. in the Weſt-Indies, adorn'd with Sculptures, Folio.
Direction for the Study of the Law. 12o.

div.head: Actus Primus,
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: I Say, It is not ſo good to be cheated as to Cheat: So I do.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Do's he mean honeſtly?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Hang honeſty, he has put me to I-know-not-how-much trouble. I vow, ſo I do.
A-Deuce take him for a knave.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Patience Sir, he did not intend—

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Intend a fool; I proteſt ſo I do, I don't know what to do, I'm ſo vext about it.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: He comes.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: How de y' Sir? Wel, what ſay you? de y' mark, I proteſt
So I do, you had almoſt hindred me of ſeeing
You; ſo you had, if you had not come as you
Did: Will you pay-in the Money, and have your Bond?

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: My fortunes bow to you.—

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: I can't abide this elegant Fortune,
Not I; My mony, My mony, Man?

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Let my Condition plead for me.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: That won't: the condition of the Bond is, to pay it
Double, (de ſe?) double, I vow.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Your Honour's Merciful.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Merciful me no more than I Merciful you:
For I vow (de ſe?) get it me quickly, or Il'e
Know why you won't: ſo I will as I live-law.
Go bid Berania come to me, do ſo.
Well, how now Berania, what ſay you to me about
Litus? I proteſt, I believe he looks like a rich Man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: More tortures yet! The harmleſs dove purſu'd
By threatning death from the Jar-falcons Talons,
Avoyds that cruel touch, and lives ſecure;
My duty checks too great a ſcorn but Love.
Can utter ſtranger to his qualities,
Free me from Inquiſitions, worſe then Death?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well then, you won't ha' him? Il'e tell him the
Long and the ſhort of the buſineſs, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange to ſee wealths power more then the ſtrength
Of Vertue, ſtack't by Craeſus his falſe fame;
Mony's Lord Paramount, and Riches ſway
My Fathers fancy, for a prudent Soul
Content's a Paradice, as unknown to moſt,
As are the furtheſt Limits of Euphrates.
Every Senſe turns Secretary, to record
His or my own hard Fortune, yielding's fatal;
I have ſet my Reſolution, and I'le ſee
Myſelf Incloyſtred e're his wife Il'e bee.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Well, how ſtands the wind of your Daughter's Good liking?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l:
Why I proteſt-law it was ſo ſharp North (ſo
〈◊〉
〈◊〉 , that it had like to ha blown my Noſe
Away, I vow, ſo ſoon as I mentioned you to her;
Law-ye.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Be plain.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Why, the Long and the ſhort is, de ſe? ſhe ſay's, ſhe
Won't have you, I am in haſte I vow, good b'y.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: To Fortune's Jiggs the vulgar ſort apply
An arm'd reſiſtance, whoſe weak affronts
Dare not conſult with Paſſion, unleſs
It ſings their requies ſum: To love
Is to be reſolute, our wealth's a bleſſing
To be contemn'd by none but thoſe whoſe thoughts
Fly to a Pin-feather'd Philoſophy,
And uſe a Microſcope, mounted on wings
Of rare devotion to ſee if the World be any thing:
My blood thaw's ſilence at a womans ſcorn;
Stay till I come.

sp.speaker: 1. Foot-Boy.
sp.p: My Lord will have her ſure, if Means can do it.

sp.speaker: 2. Foot-Boy.
sp.p: He's too well known, to be belov'd by her.

sp.speaker: 1. Foot-Boy.
sp.l: In his land her denial may walk ſo far,
Tell it's weary ſteps, and forget itſelf.

sp.speaker: 2. Foot-Boy.
sp.p: I don't know what they'l do.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Go deliver this Letter to Madam Berania,
The labour of a ſtrict perſute,
Is recompenc't by handling the Prize.
Delay, like Poppy, invites to a ſleep,
That cutting news ſhould be the hardlier felt.
Provide a bow for ſmiles: but if diſdain;
I'le get by Force what fair Means can't obtain.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Your ſyllables make worſe than baniſhment:
More captive to impiety, then the unwearied Paſſenger
Toth' fained mourning of a Crocodile
Whoſe jaws, while reeking in the bloud of thoſe
His laſt allurements ſung ſad Dirge's to,
Seeks larger Preys.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: May duty teach my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A Nobler leſſon than Rebellion prompts to.
Recant your error, ſo your Reaſon may
A Proſpect of all happineſs ſeem clear
As day, whoſe Minut • are ſeldom favour'd by
Such ſmiles of Chance, as thoſe were proffer'd you:
Reſolve amendment; to your changed mind
The Golden Sands of Factolus come flowing;
Imbrace Honour.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: By nouriſhing the hopes of Litus, whoſe ſoul,
As ſad as Niobe's, takes pleaſure
In throwing down the Gems that dwel in it.
His Birth ne'r taught him Courtſhip for a Maid
Below it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: His raſhneſs, like a Warrant,
Seconds his malice: to theſe I am an Enemy,
Had he no more blaſts of Morality.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: To call him raſh is Paſſionate, Paſſionate witty,
An ornament to Youth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Malicious too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Hatred's a Puritan compair'd, and frowns
To ſee you learn your leſſon but by halves,
Too openly bore down his friends at this.
Would keep the Scent, and were you a Man,
Turn bloud-hounds, ore-turn weapons 'til revenge
Had gi'n the Lye, to all that dare maintain
Him otherwiſe then a Fable, he ſighs
Meekly for you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He's worſe then Savage, that to get his will,
Won't Fawn and Flatter; but denyed ſtill,
His expectation ſuddenly converts
His faigned Love to hatred and imparts
Envy to Force, till with his wile he gets
His own deſire, by 'Proteus Changing fits.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: All fancies Suppoſitions worſe, his wealth
It's ſo weighty, 'twould quickly ſurprize
The ſwelling of a crook-back't quality,
Nobles are a Pumice, hard enough to grinde
His errors into nothing.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Rich and Noble,
Be coverlids of vices wrong, 'tis pitty
Who's greateſt fit to govern, he's not fit
To govern others, that cannot rule himſelf,
They ſhould grow big together, Pliny never
Mockt Phyſick better. He comes, I'le not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: To paint out to my ſelf the warlick Trophies,
Due to a Conqueror, of all that's bad
And ſtrong; the ſtoln hours
Of Leander and Hero, when the Helleſpont
Was but a Kennel to him; argues their joys,
Pigmies Fiction ſhort of truth: my Senſe
Has made no Plaudit, 'til your Siſter
Seem'd checking my haſty courtſhip, with a brow
Clear of Anger.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: A pleaſant Landskip!

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Falſe.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: A Dream, may be.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Worſe.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: My Induſtry may embalm your hopes.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: I come ſenſeleſs here with equal paſſion,
Heaven or hell mop't to a Bul-begger;
I Tantalize my ſelf, ſuch a dul Agent
Deſerves to ſee a foolliſh Meſſenger
Bring back his Letters, covered wich the mocks
Of a Chamber-maid. Harpes, true Harpes, come,
Why ſtay'ſt ſo long? 'Its paſt the time you promiſt.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: An't I within my time, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: No leſs
Then Ten pound, for an hours work: what ſay'ſt?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: Propoſe.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Truſty; ha'ſt forgot that Vertue?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: My Bonus Genius, I am ne'r without it.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Canſt' Fight?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: No matter: I can murder, may be, without it.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Piſh you are wide o'th' mark,
We are about Venial ſins.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: Nay that's the mark I'de aim at.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: A Lady, I'de ha'you and I ſteal from her Father.
Every night they walk at ſix a clock here:
Her Father • s an old fool can't fight,
Be ready: But if we are caught, canſt ſwear?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: If I can't ſwear, I can doe nothing.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Get a Coach ready at ſix a clock preciſely,
Then meet me here.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Lord Lidorus, Lord Petus, attended.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: What Friar grac't his Order by a Miracle,
In Spelling you to a Platonick love?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Reſolves after Deliberation make
A Circle; in whoſe Center, the beſt life
Lyes hid on puny ſpirits ſuch as boaſt
They have the Summum Bonum when they tread
In an old Mark made by their Miſtris Shoo;
I'le beſtow pitty.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: To receiv't agen,
When tired with burdens of a way to Honour;
Your Motion's quick, your Hands gripe labour, Mind
Reſolute to advancement, purchaſt by
A weary diligence: a Ladies lap
Inchants your purpoſe to a ſolitude,
That into ſleep, ſleep to a dream, whoſe language
Courts you to ſweetneſs inconceiveable:
As Conſiderations of Eternity.
A Thouſand preſidents, bewail loſt time, in your condition.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He's well can beware of others Harms,
Example don't excuſe a Fault,
Love-ſick's a great one.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Hold, a line of this ſubject.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Let's hear it.

lg.l: O Sacred! Sacred Love,
earths chiefest joys above!
That with thy nimble bow,
take'ſt pride to ſtick below
Thrice happy he whoſe Heart hath felt,
the quiver of thy Golden belt.
When Moping ſpirits Muſe,
what pleaſure here to chuſe.
Then Love's great ſhrine draws nigh,
with enterprizes high,
To ſway Mens hearts and wrap them Eeven,
to joyes divine, a taſte of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Parturiunt Montes. To our buſineſs.
Letters Inform me of the neer approach of Death toth' Reverend
Old Man: already 'tas took up all but his breath-room:
Thoſe Induſtrious hands that have ſo often acted his words,
When they moved Audients paſſions to Love,
To Hate, to Mirth, to Tragedy,
Have now nothing to do but ſecond fervent Prayers for you and I.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: I'me promiſed news to day.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I expect ſome too.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: At ſix a clock let's meet here,
We'll impart the Novelty of each ſtop,
And drown the time with tears that ſpeaks him dead.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'T may fall out not ſo. Starrs, and the b • ſt of Men,
Do riſe to ſet, and ſet to riſe agen.

div.stage: Enter Occus, Loſana, Thele, Berania, Hacca, Hare, and Beucer.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well, how now, Mr. Hare? well, de ſe? I don't know
I vow, Oh will you pay in the Money, law-ye?
And have the Bond?

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: You let others have it: upon that condition,
I told you of, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Sir I doe, and I do not.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: How do you then?

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.p: Very well, but that's nothing: my Money, Man!

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: I'le provide it,

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Good-buy: come Daughters, it's almoſt time to walk,
As I live, ſo it is, i'th' Garden: ſo I doe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Will you bear us company?

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: My hours an't my own.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well Beucer, you ſe (ſo do you,) that this Hare
Won't pay-in the Mony, ſo he won't,
I Vow now, de ſe, you may go if you will, I don't
Need your Witnes-manſhip.
Come Daughter I'l walk preſently, as I live law-ye:
And tell you, you are a Fool! ſo I will, I vow, for not
Marrying the Gentle-man.

div.stage: Enter Harpes, and L • tus, with a Beard.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I ſhan't be known, well Harpes art' reſolved?

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.l: My horſe needs nothing but a Silver ſpur,
To haſten it on in ſuch an Ambuſcado.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She's leight, my Boy, we'll carry her with eaſe.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.l: Leight! All the ſex are ſo, Shee has been too leight
For you already, you may ſpeak Probatum.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Stand in that corner you, but fir • t provide
A Sword to fright the old Man, the young one's got
The ſooner.
Honour's not repaid with Checks.
If her eſtate be it bladder's her Pride
I excell it; if her birth excell, that too.
Theſe things well weighed, my breſt's too generous;
To be ſubmiſſive, and, at a Woman's ſcorn,
Turn Novice.

sp.speaker: Harpes.
sp.p: A cold Iron!

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Hot enough to make him run, as Firebrands do
The Beaſts of Greenland within that place:
I'm here. Let 'um walk a turn or two, we may
Take 'um at the more advantage.
Harpes, Coach waits.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Are you ready, Sir?

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: I'm ready to blow my fingers, they'r ſo cold I vow,
So I am.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Haſte Petus to his Elegy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord, Lord Petus ſtayes to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Bid him come in, and bring hither a Table.

div.stage: Enter Petus, Boy ſets down the Table, & exit

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: He's gone, thoſe Enſigns of Honour;
Your proper due Succeſſion uſhers in.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: His Monuments.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Rich with the power of a holy Relique,
Read it.

div.stage: Harpes and Litus ſet on Berania.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Hark; the cry of ſome diſtreſt Gentlewoman!

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: At the ſight of a Frog.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Hark, hark, in earneſt let's run.

div.stage: (They run and ſee her between them.) Occus crying.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Diſhonourable Villains! what Commiſſion?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Our fancy's to your coſt.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: We'l try, provide.

div.stage: Occus creeps under the table, and peeps.
Enter Occus from under the Table.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: The Rogues! pittiful unvalourful Dogs! I was mad as
I live-law, to ſee what Cowards they were, I vow,
To ſet on us as we were walking: but I
Wiſht 'um hang'd in heat of blood; as I'm here,
So I did: thank the Gentlemen, Daughter, that
Have ſo finely delivered you.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
To your protectors I'le be devout,
And beg for a reward due to your Vertue;
All the entreaties of a bended knee
Shall guard my Sacrifice till courteous Heavens
Know the deliverance of an innocent Maid.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Confirm we have ſerv'd you by excepting it,
The Gods make apprehenſions of a Traytor,
Confound himſelf, his means, all dy'd with horrour,
Speaks daggers to his guilty ſoul, and ſaves
His enemy a triall.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: My life payes tribute to your valour.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: If it be valour, Madam, we no way
Can gueſs it's riſing, but from the bright day
Of your own Beauties, which great Nature throws,
And duty ties to the hearts of all thoſe
As profeſs honour.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Humble thanks your licent to my departure.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Your obliged Servants.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, I proteſt, ſo I do, this is a
Great kindneſs; and I vow, I don't know how to
Make you amends, ſo I don't: but good by.
I would thank you a great deal longer, as I
Live-law (de ſe?) but I vow I am a going home.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Do'ſt know this pretty Gentlewoman, prithee?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Why d'ye ask?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Her Wit, Beauties, and Behaviour are excellent.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Surprized indeed.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Be impartial to a Corrector.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Maintain it who are moſt ſecure
From Love his torments, ſooneſt do endure.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: What ſudden paſſion, like damp news of death,
Conjures my blood about my heart grown weak?
Becauſe I can't expound a petty riddle
Delivered her, what then? I'le ne're believe,
I alwayes dream'd till now I ha' been Garlick,
Deſtructive to Love's adamantick vertue;
Her very poſture how it preſents it ſelf
Before my intellect, as a true prologue
To ſome future and ſtronger invaſion.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Prefer the memory of thoſe Gentlemen;
Doubtleſs, Madam, they were ſome that knew you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Not one thunderbolt to kill this monſter?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Trouble findes eaſe when open'd, Madam,
To my obedience here's, my life. Your counſel
Is further from my mouth than Mahometiſm.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: He in the beard had the voice of Litus.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Monſtrous villany! Can ſo foul intents
Lie i'th pavement of ſo ſmooth diſguiſe?
The world's deceitful, who by fair words,
Credit, performances juſt and honourable,
Finde one is empty, the other void,
Perfidious.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I wiſh all been't ſo.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: That all for one be blam'd, Heavens forbid!
Though foul pretences under fair he hid;
Yet miſchief gathers miſchief, and who thought
Others to catch, in his own net is caught.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Providence may pay him ſo.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Let my induſtry eaſe you of theſe ſighs,
Your Siſter's with him often.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Innocence is preſerv'd by Angels.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Be it criminal, and take away my life,
To ſpeak my Miſtreſs Secrets; tell me, Madam,
What I ha' been I'le ever be,
In life a truſt, to death fidelity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Inquire the names of the two Gentlemen
That reſcu'd me, deſcribe the blackeſt moſt.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: You love, I will dear Madam when I ha' done:
He begs admittance to kiſs your hand.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Huſh, here's my Siſters Maid, be intimate, enquire.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: What ſhe knows is my own already.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Madam, your Siſter prayes your company.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I'le go my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: Do'nt Litus often wait upon your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Yes, ſhee'd have her Siſter marry him;
His treachery ha's burthen'd all mens ears.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: worſe than a Rape.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Who told you?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: I was by, and ſee it my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Since you know it, no longer I'le deny
Her private malice, his invet'racy

sp.speaker: Hacca;
sp.l: Shall be no more the cauſe of diſcontents,
To expectation happen croſs events.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: IT's all as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.p: Your Pilot taught you that trick.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I loſt my ſilver Hatband aboard.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.l: You thought ſhe had been a prey conveighed thither;
By Cidnappers upon that built your hopes,
That Virginia would a nurſt your Baſtards:
Inſtead of writing your Maſters Accounts,
Nothing was heard but, pray give Miſtreſs Sarah
More Punch, white Bisket, Oyl to her Fiſh; her mother
Will oyl your Fiſh.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: By this hand I'de not love
A Wench as well as thou for more money
Than you got by Annoque-Tobacco laſt year.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.l: You love ſmoak too 'tis a ſign, or elſe
You'd ne're a crept i'th' Stow.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: But ſay, Wilt marry her? I'le adde to the Summe.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.p: Marry, I may do ſo.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.p: I don't love Flie-blows tho, farewell.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: It's eaſie to do that with one finger
Can't be remedied: my buſineſs don't fadge.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Did you ſee Hacca?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: How long ha' you been here?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Pray tell me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: The man's in a maze ſure.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: I'me in a maze ſure enough with your face.
That ſure is a Screech-owl to my advancement;
I wiſh I had a Wife, to ſpoil this ugly buſineſs,
This Gentlewoman's better, my conſcience
Is i'th' Spaniſh mode, I'le ſee to get her:
Her name's Thele; my Schoolmaſter I remember
S'ed, the Beaſt Hyena had that in her
Would be witch a man to love: I think
This Maid ha's ſome Hyena in her too,
I have a Book at home ſ'es, Marriage is
Honourable, but it is good to be honourable.
I'le take another courſe, uſe this no more,
It's better love a Wife, than keep a Whore.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Imperial Madam, Could no lucky merit
Reſiſt the charm of an inſulting paſſion?
A foe as juſt as cruel, reſents affronts
With rage, impetuous beyond proud Tarquin,
I'le do more penance than a Gally-Slave,
That ſpurns his thraldom with laborious ſtrokes:
Eager to anticipate his deſtiny,
I'me guilty to expoliate my crime.
As your deſpiſer ſtrike my heart aſſunder,
But ſave the Love within it, carry it to her,
And tell my own words did it, may be then
One Tear may fall to glue it up agen.

div.stage: Enter Litus Covert from the Wood.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: A vow, as fatal to my purpoſes,
As his wiſht Sword, whoſe gliſt'ring brandiſhings
Makes accents to his words, commands attention:
Muſt I be pillored to diſhonour, ſtand
The moveleſs ſubject of both their hiſſes:
'Tis for Berania dye or cut through throngs
Of danger, were revenge i'th' ſame place,
Her favour ſhould a grac't, ſurprize his chants,
E're they cleave air, and come unto her ear.
I ſpeak of things above me, to his ſtrength
My wounds ſet ſeal, may be he's innocent;
Then 'twould be baſe to intend a miſchief, change
Thy fury into reaſon, may chance that may
Invent a ſafer and ſecurer way.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What Bird has croſt thy way? and drove you back
With Omens to our meeting, tell me prithee:
I'm Miſerable of all lovers, that love
And dare not reveal it.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: Nothing but Sunſhine to our intents, Madam
Why grieve you? To your ſmiles I'le bett my Honour,
He ſuffers more for you, than you for him.
I ſee his blood daunt in his face: as if
It were Eclipſt, and ſtrove to maſter Love.
His eyes were ſteddy, you paid it again;
Not without checks to thoſe inamoring Lamps,
For taking ſo much liberty.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Recount your Progreſs, to me diſſemble nothing.
Ha'ſt ſpok to him? if he be ſworn already
To ſerve another Miſtris, I'le but weep,
And ſing her happineſs, where ſigns ſhall keep
Time to my Song, and part each line from other.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: 'Tis no ſuch matter Madam; let us make
This hour remarkable, by finding out
A way may eaſe us, and reſolve our doubt:
I'le do it thus.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: I'le go a purpoſe, to ask if he took
The ſword from him, that had the black beard on;
Pretending your miſdeem is ſingly plac't:
And could by ſeeing the ſword judge who it was
Before he anſwers: a diſſembled qualm
Shall beg my excuſe, for leaving him ſo quickly,
He comes my life for't, to reſolve your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I like it, go, let providence beſpeak
A crown for this impoſture 't may deſerve one.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: If Love won't, pray let Pitty, of your oths
And earneſt promiſes, incite you to
A kinder ſatisfaction for my Honour.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: What, alwayes haunted with you as a Ghoſt?
I ha' found me a new Love: Seek you one too.
Admetus told me what would come of me • ling with Sluts:
I loſt my Silver Hat-band aboard, following him about.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: Conſider, how your ſelf ſwore and proteſted,
You were enamoured, of my poor Beauty;
Let the remembrance of your former Love
Be a privation, to your preſent Hate.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: Why? reſt contented, I tell you, if you had not
Been ſo free of your fleſh, I ſhould a loved you ſtill:
And according to Plato, I may agen.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: Juſtly diſdained Sarah, now thou reap'ſt;
The fruits of thy o're fond credulity.
How oft might I have been candidly intreated?
Had I not thrown away my ſelf upon
The Charybdes of his flattery; which brings
Me to the Scilly of this extremity
To repair my eſteem, by his enjoyment,
Or take revenge for his diſloyalty.
Away! ſhould I, under a nother's name
Diſguiſed, ſeek to vindicate my ſelf
Or reputation, a las I may dye,
I love him too well, uſe fair means, Il'e humbly
Go and complain to Mother, and ſeek her help.
To urge affection, Treaſon lets refrain,
What meekneſs can't? Malice will ne're obtain.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.l: Oh! my Daughter! my Daughter! my Child! my
Chick! Where haſt' been my Love?
Come pretty Sarah, I have not ſeen you I
Know not when.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Man is but Mortal, his reſolves more brittle
Than Ice a minute old: Certainty
Reſts til 't'as breath, and fly's away agen
For one new reaſon, all faculties ſtrike ſail;
But ſundry paſſions we are ſubject to,
Make Civil-war: then to the victor muſt
A pleaſing object be preſented. Love
Revels in's humours: What ſad ditty is this?

lg.l: Help eaſe great Powers, Why do you thus prevent me,
And laughing takes a pride still to torment me?
My fears and ſorrows ſadly mourn within,
To ſee their cauſe from troubles still begin.
Then miſerable I, how ſhall I bear it:
Languiſh for Love, and yet muſt not declare it.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: I fetch her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: 'Tis he
From moaning your condition, your own plaints
Beſought me ſilence; let's confirm our friendſhip.
On your reſolve to love none, experience
Has preacht a better leſſon, then Meditation
Furniſht me with afore you ſung.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: Madam, here's the Gentleman, here's both I think.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: While hot a wound's not felt, in the amazment
Your arms gave period to, I thought of nothing
But gratitude: ſince (all things quiet) Circumſtances,
As Treaſon ſeldom goes unpuniſh't, offers
Me means of finding't out, the Sword, my Lords,
Diſcovers his Maſter's vilany if't be he,
Had either of you it from him.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: He run woo't in his hand (Madam) 'tis kept,
To cut his Conſcience when he gazes on't.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Well, how now Daughter? I proteſt (ſo I do)
I wondred where you were, I vow, your ſervant, humble Sir,
Your ſervant, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yours.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Father, to theſe Gentlemen we owe
Our reſcue in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: I vow, I think, I thought ſo, pardon me Sirs, I
Did not know you, I vow, ſo I do, why we fought
Bravely, I proteſt law-you, I was never in a worſe
Combat in my life, as I live-law, but we came
Well off (de ſee?)

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Heavens, be thanked.

sp.speaker: Oc.
sp.l: Gentlemen, will you pleaſe to drink a cup of Wine?
I vow I'de have you come in, (ſo I would,) be merry
All danger's over now, de-ſee, I pray' come in do ſo.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: We'l follow your courteſie, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Ah! Sweet Thele, Miſtris Thele love me.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: I wonder, you importune me ſo.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Thou, ſweet-ſweet-ſweet-ſweet-ſweet face,
Wo'd I had thee I'de give all the desks in my Bond.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs you are ſo charming, that
Your Rhetorick, like Orpheus his Harp, would make
Stones flye about your head.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: If you'l ha' me,
My Rhetorick ſhall make ſtones flye about your
Ah ah ah ah ah head too.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why, you are fuddl'd, you are in a pickle

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Of Cucumbers, it's ſalt to ſee you want ha me! I'me ſure.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Go ſleep: till ſober ſober carriage, then,
And better manners learnt, come we agen.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Ah my dear Duck! where ha'ſt been my Love?
Come Dear, we'l go home and ha' a pot of ale, my Love:
Alack I'm undone! help, help, help, my Delight weeps:
Who ha's hurt my Love? I'le ta' 'um away.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: If I, dear mother, have tranſgreſt the Law
Of Nature, what I expect but Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Tell me my Joy, I'le beat, kick, ſcratch, claw, bite 'm:
My Dear, who ha's hurt my Love?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Have patience Mother, and provide your car
To hear my loſs, the ſtory I'le declare,
And beg your pardon: my Lord Occus his man.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I am a'moſt mad, my Love.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Pray hear. Beucer coming aboard the Ship
Where I was then to take my leave of my Uncle,
Profeſt me Love; and with a thouſand ſighs
Mingled entreaties, ſoliced.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Come, come, come, go on quick, ſpeak my Dear.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: My good will that Heavens know I thought
Was innocent and conjugal, his laſting
Importunities and promiſes
Of Marriage took my honour from me. I
O'recome by his deluding tongue, am forc't
To wail my hard fortune, and wailing ſo,
Augment my griefs, and they augment my woe,
Without the leaſt hope of comfort.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Oh oh! I'm undone, I ha' loſt my Daughters Virginity,
Virginity, I ha' loſt my Daughters Virginity.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Pray Mother hear.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Oh! I ha' loſt my Daughters Virginity.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Good Admetus be pleaſed to relate his leaving me,
Tears ſtop my utterance.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Tell on Love, tell on Duck; tell me Sir.

sp.speaker: Admetus.
sp.l: After this the Knave diſhoneſtly leaves your Daughter,
And I believe is in love with another.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Is this true Daughter, my Joy?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: True, Mother.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I'le claw the Rogue's Noſe off.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: The entertainment was good.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Cruel Love! that takes his chief delight,
To uſe his fury, and diſplay his ſpight;
Frowning he laughs, and ſtrives to puniſh ſtill
A Wretch with death, and yet denies to kill.
I love to ſee her, and her very eye,
As ſoon as ſeen, make me diſſolve and dye.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Unleſs you'd ſhake me off, expel theſe words,
'T bewraies your folly.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I pray did you ſee Beucer the Rogue, the Villain? I'le
Claw him to pieces, the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You want not the Lion's Kall or Herb Philocraſſa,
As Naturaliſts name't, to touch her hand,
Perfume her chamber, or mingle in her drink:
S • e loves you well enough already: nothing
Diſorders notes, and breaks your harmony,
But ſilence to a friend runs open-arm'd,
The ſweeteſt meſſage of all hiſtory.
I'le be your Spokeſ-man.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Miracle of honour!

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Promiſe to meet me here betwixt thoſe Walls,
I'le ſing your Lullaby, and borrow breath
From the wing'd words of your Berania.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: My life and fortune wait upon the news.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Attend my return.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Your Siſter loves.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Any other than your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: To be diſobedient.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: And perverſe.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: More than all this.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: She ſleights your counſel, mocks your Fathers threats,
And, worſe, o're throws her modeſty: that cuſtom
Which bears out Ladies, to expect the prayers
Of ſervants kindled by a hot denial,
Is buried in her thoughts; ſhe out-does ſhame.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: Be particular.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: Among theſe Trees I heard her Lover mourn,
The giddy mixt words of a ſtrucken Soul,
Deſires Oratour for Berania.
He went, ſhe came attended by her Maid,
'Twixt his complaints and her raſh impudence,
Compariſon is loſt; ſhe ſtretcht invention
For wayes to make him know ſhe lov'd him,
Deviſes ſtratagems to ſee him, runs
The reſt of puniſhments for violating
Her ſelf, and friends to your ſerious thoughts
Contempts as plain as day; her wantonneſs
And toleration in't, it plows up duty,
Sows pride in'ts place; and, if ſuffer'd to grow,
Will o're-top your endeavours to reclaim her.
Your birth puts briars in your hand, why uſe them,
Blow down her Babel.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.l: 'Twas my Father's will
As well as mine, a miſchief 'fore 'tis hatcht
Is bended; lightly grown benums thoſe Joynts
That reach it's head: For deſperate Maladies
Let's uſe ſevere purgations. Tyrants rule
By being ſmooth'd up in their Cruelty.
Then torments pay their tutors negligence,
Who nouriſh ſucking Vices with a Flatter.
I'le break her or my ſelf, let's ſet a time.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Do it when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.l: Don't fail, till then I'le ſeem
Honey to both.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: My heart forbids me, and I'le never ſee
Her wed another that refuſed me.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: Hee's a fine Gentleman, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: His carriage puts me to a greater muſe
Than Sphinx's Riddle; What do'ſt gather Hacca
From his motions?

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.p: I'm no Diviner, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: A Gentleman, Madam, whom I dare ſpeak vertuous
In doing Juſtice, was ſurprized and taken;
He ſuffers hardſhip in his cloſe Confinement,
And ſeeks deliverance; his courteous Keeper
Craves but your hand and word for his Releaſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I know him not.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: A Stranger aſſaulted by a crew of Thieves
Already his maſters, when paſt hopes of life,
Is ſuccour'd by a noble Paſſenger,
Not without wounds to th' Victor, whoſe dumb ſigns
Seek help from him he reſcu'd: if he can,
And won't contribute to the cure of t'other,
Ean't he ingrateful?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: In the higheſt degree.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: The Pris'ner is Lord Petus, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Your Pris'ner.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: To your Graces and Beauties; 'tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I l • ke your mirth, but change your ſubject.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Millions of ſighs beg leave to kiſs your hand,
Confirm your Judgement to the caſe I put;
His flames conſume him, quench 'm with one word,
Let me haſte to his Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Twould be too coy his Service to deny,
To grant it argues too much levity.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: 'Twould not be lightneſs to reſolve a Grant,
'Tis for his Life, Madam, deny't you can't.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Love e're he ſeeks it, that's immodeſt, ſo,

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Mercy before modeſty ought to go.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yea, where the time can diſpence but of one,

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: It don't this kill that will revive alone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Let's try both then, one with the other will
More welcome be, good is diſcern'd by ill.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: To afflict one ſo caſt down wo'd be too rough,
'Tis ſin to tread what's trodden down enough.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Time future may what preſent can't produce;
Then of this favour let him make good uſe.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: I'le carry his pardon.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: The Stars take care of you, Madam,
Here's a Preſent beyond expectation;
You ſav'd your bluſhes i'th' conqueſt too.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Our inventions may ſleep hereafter.

sp.speaker: Hac.
sp.l: How finely coy you were! I ſee Diſguiſe
Is the Familiar of a Lady, Madam.
This verifies the Proverb:
Women like Shadows are, which if you ſhun,
They'l follow; but purſue 'm, away they'l run.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Miſtris, the emptineſs of my belly may tell you
How ſorry I am for my laſt offence.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Then you faſt for your looſeneſs

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Of life you mean; I can ſooner be without my
Ears than ſeeing you.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: You flatter.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Like a Magpie.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: You diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: This knocks down my ambition, if I do not wait
Upon you, that is to ſay, have your company; for
Sadneſs I am a ſecond Melpomene.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: But not half ſo grave.

div.stage: Enter Occus and Winifred with a ſtick.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Oh you Rogue Beucer, 'tis he, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: Why I vow ſo I do, this is a diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Nay, hear woman, I vow I never ſee ſuch a woman
I' my life, I proteſt ſo I do.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I ha' loſt my Daughters Virginity, the Raſcal had it
Aboard the Ship, and now leaves my Girle.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Speak ſoftly, and I'le anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Why I vow, why did you do ſo? you are a Knave;
De ſe, as I live-law, marry her, marry her.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Do, ſhe's my onely Girle, then I'le love thee my Chuck.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Be patient, ſhe's handſom I muſt needs confeſs.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why law-now he may marry her in time.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: If he don't, my Lord, I'le ſcratch the Rogue.

div.stage: Enter Berania, Hacca, Loſana, and Thele.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Here's my Father, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: I Daughters I am here about an ugly buſineſs:
I vow I wiſh the Devil had it, ſo I do.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: Pray Sir tell it us.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I vow one thing comes before another, that I can't
Speak a word, I'm ſo vext, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: Pray Sir tell it us.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I will forſooth Miſtris.
My Daughters Virginity! Beucer, the Rogue Beucer
Ha's lain with my Daughter, and ſleights her.
How d' you Cozen, Beucer the Rogue ha's defil'd
My Daughters Virginity aboard a ſhip, and now ha's left her.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Ha's he ſo! (O Goodneſs!) Aunt be patient.
Is't poſſible? pray Aunt ſay nothing of it,
Till I give further order; ſeem to forget it.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I will indeed forſooth Cozen.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Beucer, how can you profeſs love to me,
And have abus'd my Cozen? It's well I know it;
May be I'le help it, Wiſdom inſtruct me in't.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well Daughters, de ſe, I'le leave you I vow.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.l: Siſter, your ſtrangeneſs troubles me; if Love
Take up your fancy, tell me, to your counſel
I'le be as faithful as your inward thoughts.
Your Looks ſpeak Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yours not Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: Truth needs no gloze, Lord Petus claims you his.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Who told you?

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.l: A Friend,
They know more than my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.l: Wan't Litus potent good enough for you?
Ha • s too much pride bewitcht you? he ſ'es true,
You do inſult, and more, if ſuffer'd, will.
It's good remedying new ſprung miſchief ſtill:
'Tis my reſolve e're you two married be,
I ha' vow'd a ſtop.

sp.speaker: Litus,
sp.p: A Tragedy.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Welcom Lidorus—.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Snatch that word agen,
Do not miſtake the livelineſs that ſits
Upon my Face is to add to perſwaſion;
That you would bear the news of doubtfull things
With a ſtay'd Courage.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Some religious man
Be fo't to prepare me for a death
To th' world and all his vanities: within
A narrow Cloyſter I'le hem in't my wiſhes;
And when the Bell rings to a rigid meeting,
Repent my earthly thoughts, and puniſh them
With hard mortifications: ſpeak my doom,
Or point it rather, let ſome dying ſign
Throw my miſfortune in my face, that I
May huſh up all in ſilence.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Take it then,
Stay'd courage leſt you ſhould be extaſi'd
With joy, and make your ſuccour your undoing,
Like thoſe are a'moſt ſtarv'd when they ſee meat,
Expire with greedineſs.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: What doubtful things
Should check my welcome to you.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Can'ſt believe
A man may be in Paradice e're he prayes for't?
Or hover amongſt Angels e're he thinks it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: As to his thoughts may be.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Then be ſo.
Upon my honour all ſhe commands you,
Is to be faithful; ſuch a glorious Flower
Ne're bloſſom'd in ſo ſhort a time before:
Her words are full of ſweetneſs, mild and fair,
Courteous as may be, free from fond allurements.
I beg'd your life, ſhe grants it, viſit her,
And find more than I tell you to be true.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Say but ſhe's mild, and I'le out-dare worſt fate,
And kind, there's ne're another word like that:
It lifts my fancy higher than the ſtory of Elizium.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Take my faith to't, mild and kind too.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Sure the Sphears ſing to beguile me;
Upon your memory ten thouſand thanks
Shall dwell: I'le publiſh how much friendſhip is
In Liſborn, in your ſelf with ſuch an accent,
'T ſhall more an imitation till the world,
Know to be honourable.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: Your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Well, how d'ye Gentlemen? d'e ſee, Sir, I am come
About a buſineſs of very great exigence as I
Live-law, ſo I am I vow the caſe is thus Law-you;
I heard you were in Love with my Daughter,
(D'e-ſee) and I vow ſhe might a had a Lord
With a great Eſtate, (d'e-ſee) but as I live-law
I am ſo much a friend to Valour, I vow, that if
You have a good Eſtate, look you, Sir, I had as
Live you ſhould have her (d'e-ſee) as any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p:
He poſſeſſes the Revenues of a noble and induſtrious
Family, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Look you, Sir, I an't for complementical words; but here
Stands the caſe, if my man Beucer ſ'es you are
A pretty Gentleman (d'e ſ'e) as to Eſtate, as I live-law
I'le preſent to my Daughters marrying you I vow, ſo
I will with all my heart: Can a man ſay more
For his heart-blood, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You are all-obliging, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why every body ſe's ſo, as I live-law: Come ſmoak
A Pipe of Tobacco at my houſe, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We attend you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: Dear Miſtris I ſigh till I am as hoarſe as a
Parrot, and cry every day, I beſeech you love me.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: If I thought you were in earneſt, I'de let looſe
The reins of love, it's hard to keep 'um in;
You are ſo bewitching.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: To my fovour, my face you mean:
If I ben't in earneſt, I wiſh the hands of a
Pick-pocket may deprive me of my Looking-glaſs,
Before I ſee home.

div.stage: Pulls out a glaſs and looks in't.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: A deep curſe, is it ſo precious?

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: A repreſentitive of the external faculties of the
Face; or rather to talk elegantly: The lively object
Of Beauty or deformity; In which we view as it were
The heart through the eyes.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Theſe are high words indeed,
To be no longer woo'd, I love: and think
The day too long till wee are Married.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: I am mad with joy! Your goodneſs! Your goodneſs!

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Ben't carried away with every beauty,
And leave me; ſeeing I have been ſo free:
And opened my ſelf to you, I could not help it;
Every ſight of you made my ſtomack dance.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Will you grant one favour, ſweet Miſtriſs?

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: In Modeſty, what is't?

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Cool me a little Miſtriſs, it's my modeſty makes Me mince it ſo.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Are you hot then?

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: Oh! Beyond the Superlitive degree far, alas, that is to ſay,
Otherwiſe tormented, you don't know how I burn!

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: You an't burnt yet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: But ſcorcht very much, adde that favour to the reſt.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: My Service is due to you as my Husband, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: Give me leave to ſatisfie my ſelf with you now,
And then, I ſhall dye without it, ſweet Love.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'le obey your will vertuouſly inclin'd, Sir, but
I don't know what you mean.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: Onely your company.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Henceforth command it.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.p: And the ſight of Alablaſter Legs, Miſtris.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Away, Sir, that muſt crown our Marriage;
Rejoyce in this your ſincerity made you the
Firſt in my favour.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: I do indeed, this Verſe of my own making tells you
So; for I had a good ſign that you would
Love me: A Raven cried, Marry, Marry, at my
Chamber-window afore-day;
Now I have all, what elſe can I implore?
I ha' got my Love, and I deſire no more.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Beu.
sp.l: A very good Verſe, we call it a Heroick, it ha's
Juſt ten feet, which is the Orthodox Rule
Of our Modern Poets.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The Fool, or rather Knave, thinks I am enamour'd;
I am ſo but to ſee my Cozen vindicated:
Heavens have heard my prayers, and ſmile down
A perfect grant to our own intents;
He ſleeps in's pranks ſecurely, little dreaming
That I am privy to his waggery.
How men ſpeak double to enſnare our Sex
With gilded words, when all their purpoſes
Are more remote than Eaſt from Weſt, I wiſh
I could but ſpeak with her: Boy, you boy.
Go to Sarah Moren, and tell her I ſtay to
Speak with her.
Poor Maid, how ſhe builds Caſtles in the Air,
And dreams of peace if he'd love her again:
Such is the thoughts of pleaſure after pain.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Here, here Cozen, here's my Daughter, my Duck;
I came running in ſuch haſte, that I ſweat
Intollerably.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Dear Cozen, I threw away ſadneſs at your meſſage,
Thinking it might have good news in it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſent to renew my former charge that you
Would carry all things cloſe and huſh, and you,
Aunt Winifred.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I forſooth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be not ſo mad and furious
With Beucer, 'tmay contribute to your good.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I forſooth: I will indeed forſooth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: My Miſtris expects me. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Now Daughter, this is brave i'faith! this is gallant!
Hie Boyes! my Daughter, my Duck.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Let things be carried on in courſe, I ha' found
Fortune ſo fickle, that I can't repoſe
Truſt to a benefit before I ſe't.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Well, my Dear, I'le do ſo too my Joy, ſo I will my Love.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: 'Tis poſſible to ſee good dayes once more,
Till then ſubmit to that miſhap it may be,
To others common in this world we ſee,
Nothing that's conſtant but inconſtancy.
Not to remedy, yet to grutch is vain;
Uſe patience where we can't redreſs our pain:
The darkeſt nights bright morning ſtill enſue,
After grief joy.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: It may be ſo with you.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: You Tom, this way mon.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: I ſaw their faces, they were like a Queen for gallantry.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You make a fool of one, ſo you do.

sp.speaker: First.
sp.p: I tell you you lie.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Then they'd be here afore now.

sp.speaker: Recorders:
sp.l: A Scene diſcovering Petus ſleeping in a Field, four
Nymphs lay their hands on him, and ſing.

sp.speaker: 1. Nym.
sp.l: I freely here thy pleaſure: pronounce in Joys rich Banket;
O happy thee, whoſe eyes ſhall ſee: ſuch bliſs great love be thanked.

sp.speaker: 2. Nym.
sp.l: Your prayers are accepted: her heart doth well affect thee;
Venus affirms, her Son from harms: of envy ſhall protect thee.

sp.speaker: 3. Nym.
sp.l: My coming warns thee, Petus, of diſaſters,
Which with a hare thy head hang quivering over;
The Gods agree, no remedy
Shall ſave thy mirth, O harmleſs Lover.
By Fate ordain'd, e're thou wert nam'd,
A ſudden hate thy Love ſhall cover.

sp.speaker: 4. Nym.
sp.l: Then reſt contented, till the time's expired;
This paſt, your Joyes ſhall once again renew,
Thy fury will, lead thee to ill,
Of fight, and almoſt murther too:
Before the ſpace of many dayes,
What we predict, you'l find it true.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Apollo's will's obey'd, let us addreſs
Our Nymphly poſture to the Wilderneſs.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.l: You Rogue you came too late; here was the
Rareſt ſinging that e're you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Rare! all mirth I brave Maids! I believe they were Spirits.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: You kiſs my—Fool, they were Women.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: So they were, we ſee 'um go you way mon.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: They ſung, and did ſo faſhion.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: I can tell beſt, they ſung ſo.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: What, what Gentleman's this?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: U • ſnigs, look here you, here's a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: Law-ya-now, you muſt pay ten groats for Swearing.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: What, in jeaſt you Puppy.

sp.speaker: Firſt and ſecond.
sp.p: He's no more Puppy than your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.l: Who ſ'es he is? remember this
When you come in our ground.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: There you may ſtay for me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Coward, a Coward, ah ha, aha.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: What Viſion dare controul my quiet? Now
I'm Berania's I'le meet the ſhapes of night,
And jear their threat'nings, gaze on buſie Spirits,
That would tempt men to dread their helliſh Rhimes,
A power garriſons me from the mumblings
Of huge Succubuſſes, whoſe weighty load
Preſſes mens folly, makes a ſpill, and then
Turns to a Propheſie as falſe as may be.
Till now I fear'd to have the idle actions
Of a diſturb'd brain, leſt it had figur'd out
Some omen to my aim; but ſince ſhe's mine,
Im not deluded with the lovely ſhape
Of falleſt Nymphs that bleſs me in a Tune,
Nor pant a'th' curſes of the two laſt Siſters.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What makes you look ſo ſad, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Apparitions.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: They ſay I ſhall be a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Some that do not know, Madam, what ſtrength I fetch from every word you ſpeak to tear 'um.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Tell me the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Sleeping on this Bank,
Viewing your Idea deriv'd from my laſt thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: When it is not yours, let it be deaths.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A ſhape too grim, my Lord; but pray tell on.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A couple of Maids, I like't them pretty well,
Aſſur'd me of my Heven, your ſelf, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No Heven.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I'de loſe ten thouſand lives for't.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Angels
Ordain you for a better.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Two came after.
Put clouds upon my hopes, and ſtrove to vail 'um
With darts of envy, as thick as ſhowers of hail.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Shine clearer by contemning fooleries.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I'le change them to ambition, that you
Inſtruct me to't, and ſpeak what's in my minde,
A dream, it happens, by contraries this ha's;
'Twas trouble, till now this pleaſant Meadows could not
Be ſweet by the preſence of Berania,
Nor I bleſt with ſuch an encounter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Dreams are but fancies, and who grieve or joy
At their portendment, dread and fear a toy.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Miſhap o' Beucer for me, as I live-law he's an arrant
Knave, I vow; well, how d'ye my Lord? we come I vow to
See what you'l do about Marriage: I proteſt, ſo I
Do, d'ye love her ſtill? I vow I ask becauſe I don't
See you prate and talk, and hug her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To anſwer your demands is not—

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: To ſpeak, we know your mind, an imprecation
Tail'd with a ſigh, and ſilence is enough
To your favour, Madam, this man owes—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Inquiry how you pleaded for him.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: A Lawyer are you?

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: What's your Fee, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: But to kiſs your hand;
Then I'le confine your angry brow to limits,
Your ſervants dye elſe, take a Preſident.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: A Gipſie can't ſpeak more, know things aforehand.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: I'le work that wonder, Madam, he confirms; Points to Petus. I ha' ſtudied Phiſnomy, told him his fortune.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: His impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To you?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: He'd ſooner ſpeak a line without a vowel,
Than leave abuſing, thoſe were Ladies Servants.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: It's puniſht with a great deal of ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: D'ye talk of trouble and ſorrow already, (d'e-ſee?)

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: She ſpeaks backwards, Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why, I vow that's the way to raiſe the devil, they
Say to ſpeak backwards, ſo they do, don't, don't I pray.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No Sir, the Devil is raiſed by a Planetae impoſitione Retrogreſſa, as they call it.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: What's that? what is it like?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why I vow, it's like to fright me out of my wits,
So it is, to hear you talk ſo barbaſtically of
Old-Nick, as I live-law.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: Language will be cheap, my Father farms it.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.p: Come, come prithee.

div.stage: Enter Hare, and three other Comrades.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Troth I am vext at the old Fool Occus, he ha's
Got a Pond of me for almoſt two hundred Pounds,
And no Witneſs but my Hand and Seal, (I would I had it)
And the Dorerd keeps ſuch a quarter to have in
His money, that I can't reſt for him, and to
Disbarſt ſo much I can't neither: He's an old doting
Fool as ever I ſee.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.l: Why don't you make one of him, and get your
Bond then?

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: May-be he's a cunning Fool.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: I rather think ſo.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Here ſtands the buſineſs, I borrowed this money to
Build two or three ſmall Houſes; afterwards I morgag'd them,
And ſpent the money, and now this old Lord Fool
Would have me pay it. —

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.l: We can tell your meaning, you would put a trick
Upon him, and get the Bond without money.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.l: Why faith I would and I know companions you
Are very ready in ſuch buſineſſes, you don't vvant
Wit; if you do't, I'le give you forty Pounds betvveen you.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.l: I am afraid it vvould be difficult to obtain, by
Reaſon his Man Beucer ha's the keeping of it; vve
Muſt do it by a vveild.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.l: For forty Pounds vve'l venture a broken Pate.
A trick, a trick.
Hannibal oft by policy ha's got
The Fort, his military ſtrength could not.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: My true hearts be ſtout, I'le vvarrant vve do the deed.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Mr. Hare, I vow I believe you'll put me to trouble, to get my own money, ſo I do: I wonder you'll be ſo diſhoneſt, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Have patience my Lord, I am here with three men that owe me mony, to pay in yours, if I can get it: they promiſe to do their beſt for me.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Beſt and worſt, all's one to me: if you pay it in, d'ye ſee? you'll have your bond, and be out of harms way, ſo you will.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Why I tell you Sir, ſtay but till theſe men tell me what they'll do, and I'll have my bond.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why law you, becauſe you are my friend I'll ſtay ſo long, ſo I will; but I vow, no longer, ſo I won't.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: 'Twas well you ſaid we owed you mony; a good conceit.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: You hear him ſay he'll be delayed no longer, it will be worth our time, prethy gentlemen lets plot quickly; the reward as ſoon as the work's perform'd.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.l: You ſpeak nobly, lets lay our heads together
To get the Paper, let our Genius tend,
And if we looſe our labour there's an end.
sp.stage: Walk about a turn or two.
sp.p: Look here Sirs, I conceive this will be the beſt way, one of us ſhall go and tell Occus that he believes Hare is in a very poor condition; and that he believes Occus will looſe his mony, if he don't look after him, but ſhall diſſwade him from arreſting him, for fear that undoes him, &c. Then if he requires counſel in this caſe, he ſhall tell him, that he knows a cunning man, to whom if he goes with his bond, he's ſure he can give him good advice.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Well ſaid, by this hand thou haſt a politick pate of thy own.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p:
Then I'm ſure he'll go, for the old fool will ask of the Devil before he'll looſe his mony: then one of you ſhall be the Conjurer: when he comes, dont ask to ſee the bond, leſt it beget ſuſpition; for Beucer has taught him not to truſt his Father with ſuch things: but make a Circle. You Mr. Hare ſhall be dreſt like a Devil: ſtrange words we muſt uſe (but my life for't) rather
then he'll be torn to pieces, he throws down the bond; if ſo, take it up and keep it.
Hare ſhall be the Devil; you the Conjurer (to the ſecond;) and I'll be his perſwader.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Go attire your ſelf (to Hare:) And you Mr. Conjurer be ready at a call.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: I will, I warrant you: do you ſtand and ſee private (to the firſt man,) I'll to perſwade him.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.l: I ſhall get my part of Forty pounds for ſeeing
A trick; I'd be hired ſo always; it's good.
Mony, and pleaſure too, 's a double gain:
I'll have the cole, and they may ſhare the pain.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: I came a purpoſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well Sir, what d'ye ſay?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: My Lord, love to you bids me tell you of a thing that may ſomething concern you.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: What is't? what is't, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Sir, I hear Mr. Hare oweth you nigh two hundred pounds; he is in a very poor condition, and I believe, except you get it of him very ſuddenly, you will looſe it, for he is down the winde.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why I vow, ſo I do, I'll arreſt him, ſo I will, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: No, Sir, then he's an undone man, you'll ne'er get it ſo.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why, what would you ha'me do, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Here liveth a cunning man hard by, that is able to reſolve you in all ſuch points, how you ſhall get your mony, for a ſmall piece.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Prethy tell me where he lives, I proteſt I'll go to him, I vow, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Stay, my Lord, I'll go fetch him, he lives at next door.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p:
Why, I vow, I think I was wrapt in my Mothers ſmock,
ſo I do, every body loves me ſo, ſo they do, I vow, to tell me how to get my money, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: This is he, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why, Sir, after humble commendations, I vow, there is a man, his man is Mr. Hare, as I'm here, a duce take him for a knave, oweth me almoſt two hundred pounds, and he won't pay me, I vow: I came to ask your counſel, ſo I do, for a ſmall piece, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Have you brought your bond, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I'll fetch it, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Now for my ſkill.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Here it is, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: I have buſineſs, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.l: Well, will you ſtand ſtill?
I, I, I, I, I, vow.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Your mony comes, my Lord, all to you, I'll warrant you, when we have made a Scheme; Earth and Saturn, you'll have it.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: My Lord, you will ſtand ſtill be ſure.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Shall I ha' my mony then?

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: No fear: hold up your bond in your right hand.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: I, I will hold it as faſt as you will, I vow.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.l: Hy ſurge tu grande nebulo.
Iterum per nomen Poldavi ſurge.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.l: Satan I defie thee, Satan I defie thee, d'ye ſee?
O I'll ha'no mony, I'll ha'no mony.

div.stage: Conjurer goes behind Occus and holds him.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Throw down the bond, or we ſhall be torn.

div.stage: Occus goes to throw it down twice or thrice, and pulls back.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: I'th' Red Sea for ever, i'th' Red Sea lay him.

sp.speaker: Conjurer.
sp.p: Down with it, or you dye.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: O good, O good.

div.stage: Throws down the bond, and runs away.
Devil takes it up, unvails his face.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Here 'tis, our will's obtain'd, our ſkill is ſhown,
The deed is done, and now the bond's my own:
Wit plays the critick, Policie keeps ſchool,
I've got my wiſh, and Devil take the fool.

div.head: ACT. IV.
SCEN. 1.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: DIſconſolate old man under an Aſpect
Shewing afflictions, were thy Infant-griefs
Conceived: Oh my Son Litus, is he dead?
Gray-hairs repoſe your ſorrow in the Grave;
Oblivious of all future happineſs;
Is he devoured? Monſtrous cruelty!
Barbariſm in wilde Beaſts; could you not content
Your hungry ſtomacks, with the woful ruines
Of my deceaſed life, ſo often walking
Through diſmal Alleys of your woody territories?
But you muſt chaw the Branch of all our Race.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Be not immoderate, my Lord, in ſorrow;
May be ſome nimble Buck, while he was hunting,
Was trac'd to death by his toilſome purſuit;
Or elſe ſo far, ſome honeſt paſſer by
Muſt guide his looks to homeward: thouſand chances
Hinder intents of coming back; and yet
When he returns, makes mirth to think upon't.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: No, he's loſt.
Pray young Gentlewoman, do you hear report of Lord Litus?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: Do I dream? or is his Villany before me? I'm terrified at's thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: How dar'ſt O baſe woman
Stain my Sons honour with the name of Villain?
Unleſs your words be reaſonable, I'll make
My aged hands the tragick inſtruments
Of your untimely murther.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: Hold, my Lord, I have cauſe enough to ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Out with't quickly.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: If he's your Son, Sir, underſtand he lately
Fained to ſigh for my Miſtriſs Berania;
But ſhe knowing his raſhneſs, would not ſuffer
Him ſee, much leſs to confer with her: At which,
I weep to name it, he gave ſo much ſcope
To his vile paſſion, that he hir'd a Ruffin,
Help'd by himſelf, to force her from the Garden,
As ſhe was walking with her Father and me:
She had periſh'd, had not two young Gentlemen
Reſcu'd her fainting ſoul; they kill'd his Ruffin,
Drove him away, my Lord; and ſince that time
Shame has conceal'd him.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Swear that this is true.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: By all my love to truth.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: Now farewel comfort,
Long ſince I have predicted ſome diſaſtrous
And gloomy accident to follow his
High-minded ſtubbornneſs; Oh me, oh me!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A chair, a chair, my Lord faints.

div.stage: Enter Servant with a chair: he ſits in't.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: My ſons departure, tells me I muſt have
A doleful life, or elſe a doleful grave.
Fear ne'r to ſee him more, affrights me ſo,
It makes me loth to ſtay, and loth to go;
Leſt he ſhould live ſtill, then if I expire,
'Twould kill his joy, and kill my own deſire.
I'll tarry, perchance Heavens ſo kinde may be,
To revive my Son, and ſo to revive me.
By his return, if not, I'll yeild my breath,
Firſt due to ſorrow, and next due to death.
But why cheer I ſo? if he liv'd, ah then,
He'd ſend me news by word, or news by pen,
To eaſe my fears, or elſe expel my grief
By a quick burial, or a quick relief.
He's gone, I forgive you, now ſuffer me
To ſlide from this vale of extremity.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: My Lord, I've here one lately ſee your ſon i'th' wood hereby.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Away, kill me no more.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: What news, my Lord, has taught your eyes to weep?
Shed one tear more, and let that be beſtowed,
For not accepting croſſes as you ſhould:
The change of all things here puts you in minde,
You're toſſed like a Ball between the Rackets;
Shew your ſelf Maſter of your paſſions; uſe 'um
As a wiſe Angler, play 'um all to death.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: My ſon is buried, but where I know not.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Since this days dawning, Sir, his ſon was ſeen
Alive and well in theſe adjacent Woods.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Won't all perſwade a change, my Lord? believe it,
Breath while there's hopes, the truth is quickly known.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: How I pray?

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: If he's there, you have waies enough
For his recovery: beſeech the King
His Foreſts may be ſearch'd, and every place
Suſpected, enter'd by his Commiſſion:
The Seal makes people double diligent;
Let your reward provoke them to induſtry.

sp.speaker: Lonus
sp.p: I'll go and beg that favour of the King.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Poor man, how ſad he is!
Joy to you Miſtriſs,
Make much of your Servant Beucer.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Is he mine?
Steward, count out a hundred Dollers for her,
Your news deſerves it; till now, I could not truſt
So fair a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, never mock.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Forget to part the Caſh, add ten times more,
It's ſeconded; the Guinian Neger never
Humm'd for his paſſage more to ſerve a Maſter,
Then I at this; may it be credited?

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.p: As what you ſee.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: The buſineſs Amorous
Takes up the thoughts, awakes and conveys them
To skreeks of ſlumber; as the matter is,
A pill eant half ſo pleaſant; this has waſh'd
Diſturbance down: I can freely inquire
The love and progreſs of Berania.

sp.speaker: Hacca.
sp.l: Diſſemble what you know, all is providing;
We wiſh his voice be clear, bids 'um good morrow
After the Muſick of the Marriage-night.
My Miſtriſs airs out ſweeteſt expectation
To drive the time away.
Occus is free to't, no impediment
Stains blew proceedings, but Lord Petus Father,
Who I don't know his reaſon, keeps at diſtance,
But 'twill away, it has been motion'd twice.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Patience to hearing's the firſt ſign of grant:
He's faint, whoſe Fathers firſt repulſe doth dant.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Vile, damn'd, rotten, pockie, ugly, deviliſh Dogs, I vow, they have got my mony and my bond, ſo they have; a Devil on 'um, I'll ſee the Devil Hang'd, as I live, law ſo I will, before I'll go to him again, for a Rogue as he is, I vow, to come to cheat ſo, as I'm here: I believe the Witches ſent him: it's a damn'd thing to be a Conjurer.

div.stage: Enter King, Guard, Chancellor and Lonus.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: May't pleaſe your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Riſe up, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: To grant me one Petition 't may put off
The ſorrows that do over-whelm my heart,
For my ſons loſs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Name it, be confident,
Your former Services lye freſh within me,
I'll do more then you ask.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: Humble thanks, Sir,
Betwixt this mornings fits of fate, when ſcarce
I could wiſh any thing but to end my life,
A beam warm'd me a little; and thus it was,
My ſon was ſeen alive; grant me ſo much,
All places may be ſearched with your order:
His golden mouth that tells me tidings of him,
Shall be inrich'd with a reward that's fit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why went he away?

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.l: I know not, but being out,
Some private grief is pleas • d with wandring,
And keep him there, if he's alive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I grant it,
Give whom my Lord appoints a large Commiſſion,
To examine what's ſuſpected; wiſh you tydings.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Heavens bleſs your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Your worſhip, your honour, Majeſty, King, King, the Devil has got my bond, ſo he has, I vow, I pray give it me agen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Devil your bond, my Lord? I can't help that.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: So, ſo, this is very brave, the King can grant other things, ſo he can, I vow; but he won't grant me, ſo he wont, I ſhall be plagued ſtill; a Devil 'um all for me, that mony would a bought me and my daughter new clothes to the Wedding, ſo it would, I vow; he had a confoundable great pair of horns, ſo he had.

div.stage: Enter Hare and the three Men.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: Now our buſineſs fadg'd gallantly, it did.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: I, thank me.

sp.speaker: 3 Man.
sp.p: I got him here with a flea in his ear, to you Mr. Conjurer with your figures.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Your figures got the bond.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.l: Old Occus thought we Saints had been,
He ſee us ſtand ſo civil;
Till I took him by the ſhoulder,
And thruſt him to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Now you have your bond, let's go and have our mony.

sp.speaker: Hare.
sp.p: 'Tis due.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: My Lord Lonus ſayes I ſhall have mony enough, if I finde him.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You? I'll finde him firſt, or I'll look as Nunkle Morris does the Hedges for a Hare, faith.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Swaukers, we'll all go, go whoop and hollow, till we make him ſee, if he be to be ſeen, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: You Owls, I'll make him come with a ſuſſorarah, as the Gentle-folk ſay.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: If I finde him, I'll drink Sack with all the mony.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You drink Sack? you drink a — won't you?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Out on ſuch an unmannerly baſtard to ſay — you're a great booby.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: Hie to our work, before George.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Tell me ſome reaſon, Sir, 'tis eaſie for you
To contradict my remedy, becauſe
You have forgot its torments; yeild to it,
Requite my duty with a Fathers grant:
Did you but feel the flames I do, your own
Tortures would kneel for a whole Sea to quench 'um.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Check your pretended fancy; to my care
Commit your ſelf, I'll chuſe a match ſhall pleaſe you:
Our Countries wide, within the circle on't
I'll fetch a beauty ſhall deface your Miſtriſs,
And bring you to your right minde.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Give conſent
I marry her, or elſe command my grave;
One of them two muſt end my love or life.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: In ſons obedience beſt beſuits the minde
To Fathers precepts, as the Clouds by winde.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Yea, where obedience grees with good, 'tis ſo:
But 'tis not good to kill me; pitty ſhow.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: I will in giving what my ſelf affects.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: To pleaſe it ſelf, Love others ſtill neglects.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: Why Love approaching miſchief cannot ſee.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: If that betyde, lay all your blames on me.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: 'Tis vain to move what's fixt: Heavens bleſs your choice,
That in your joys, we both may like rejoyce;
And not to ſtrive againſt the ſtream, I here
Approve your love ſhown to your lovely deer.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Tell Berania, I am happy, ſiſter;
Heavens ſhrowd from ills: Lidorus now deſcend—

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Maſkers, or what?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Undiſguis'd, I'll ſhew
Them all the way to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Why muſt we leave you?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Underſtand me, Lady, 'tis ſo nigh,
I'll look at it as the wiſe Elephant
Adores the Moon, and uſe variety
Of contemplation to expreſs my Jubil.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Forget to ſigh then.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: I may uſe a few that 'tis no neerer.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: I'll go carry her word,
'T would be too harſh tho: won't your patience, Sir,
Make earthquakes till its ſpent?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Now what are Ladies?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Forgive, my Lord, han't I had puniſhment?
If not, I'll leave the ſeat of Cherubins
And be your Vaſſal; 'fraid to ſpeak, I'll wait
the ſloweſt motion of your hand or eye
That calls me to't again: conſult definers
Of Angels or of women; let 'um ring
With words of rapture above all the flouriſhes
Have been invented ſince the time of Rome:
I'll ſwear they ſay true, when they call 'um gods.
If this won't do, perſwade ſome gentle Beauty
To ſtick me for a year; and all that while
I'll cry its juſt, and with my lateſt breath,
Damn my condition, 'fore I was converted.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: You make us think you worſhip every thing a Lady has laid hands on.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: I, and cringe
At a white Peticote a mile from him;
Be real, and under that conſideration,
You'll finde a new world all made of delight.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: There's other things between.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: How now, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Elſe every one would make diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Women and truth are beſt, when naked, ha'
The ſweetneſs of imagination, when
Their lovely bluſhes in a pretty face
Are fancied, telling us of all our ſins.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Or but one touch of their hands charm with pleaſure:
Refiners are not half ſo jocund, Sir,
To ſee gold drops fall thick as Rain from Ore
That promiſt little.—

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: As I, my Lord, have been
About your age to dwell on the melting lips
Of thoſe ſweet Females.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Excellent, I faith, it poſts to him, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: Nothing more welcome,
I have often wiſh'd to ſee my Siſter muſe;
A reverend Prieſt would joyn 'um both together.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: What undiſcerned miſchief dare lurk private?
The aſſenting trumpets of our holy Temples,
Confound all Treaſon; her one preſence has
Power to kill the infection of an Adder
That leaps croſs their can did intentions.

sp.speaker: Loſan.
sp.l: None can be ſure of futures; every point
Of time's defended from black Maladies
By ſomething pious, or the influence
Of proſperous ſighs.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Where both are pure as they,
I'll propheſie the eights of Harmony.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Curſt not to credit you.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Your baſhfulneſs
Kept you at diſtance, like a well-bred Maſty,
Will ſee a ſhoulder of Mutton in a Diſh,
And Periſh ere he'll taſte it. 'Twas me Madam
Beat the Alarm.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Noble Centinel,
To acknowledge it, I'll wait upon your ſafety,
And beg for watch-nights to attend your perſon.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Loſana and Thele.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: Go for Litus: Thele ſtay you there,
Hell be almoſt angry I tarry ſo long.
To kill, or wound, or poyſon, ſome of theſe
Shall open to the right or left: I can't
I can't, nor won't bear it, ſee my own ſelf
Spit upon, while my younger flattering imp
Is always pray'd for and admired? away,
Let me be melted into nothing, if
I don't cure this ere I am two Suns older:
Stab me if I don't convert my promiſe
To performance. My Lord, their viſits tire
The day: Cabinets full of letters ſtand
For gold to ſtare on, every breath brings meſſage
Of new devoyrs, and returns deep loden
With Lovers whimſies: to your laſt diſcourſe
I have paid reverence, 'twas right and true:
The hodge-podge words of her phantaſtick pate
Serve for good morrow to me: all their ſtudies
Are for others to conjure one another,
In changing hearts: catalogues of their flouts
Swell when I'm amongſt 'um; every moment
I ha'been urgent in perſwaſions to her,
She has ſcorn'd 'um.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Troth Madam, I wondred you
So long together could forget your birth:
Two gallant ſpirits, their continual practice
Strikes deeper then a Chinian Dart: You know
The unfit receiving ſhe has of your counſel,
To all but who their cogging words and looks
Buy reſpect of; your Nobler minde is plain,
Kill bad examples; famous for a Pattern:
Shew their dull Genius the way to mend;
Correction's ſtudied quickly, though I muſt
Confeſs revenge is hungry at their carriage,
I thought to come ere now.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: Take this prevention, ſhortly I intend
To put in practice arms that ſhall divide 'um:
It's time enough, the more intire they,
One bullet takes two bodies glew'd together.
D'ye think I can forget their outrages?
Sooner my name and Country; I'll bear both
Fair looks till then.

sp.speaker: Litus.
