sp.l: My Father, I'm inform'd,
Has ordered for my ſearch; I'll ſooner dye
Then be diſcovered 'fore we have ended this.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: I'll flee to 't.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: If you don't, and quickly too,
I'll be contriver and Executioner:
She can't help it, may be, but my oath
Tears out the heart of one, if not of both.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: I have defer'd ſo long, dear Coſen,
In expectation of your promiſt help,
That I can't hide it longer; my ſhame begins
To increaſe: I fear without your ſudden counſel,
I ſhall be forc'd to give the world an Infant:
I bluſh to think on't.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.p: Don't do ſo, my Joy.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.p: Heal my diſtemper, uſe time while you have it.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.p: I do, do my ſweet Nephew, my love: my Daughter's with Childe for ſooth.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Be diligent, ben't abſent, ſhortly I'll ſend,
Till then I'll pray for good ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.l: Heavens grant it,
My Cauſe is juſt; what rockie heart can hear
My ſad complaints, and not relieve me? Wonders
Have brought content to th' harmleſs; let ſome viſion
Threaten his diſloyalty; and then beſeech
Him view the curſes ready to fall on him,
For taking holy things to witneſs how
Clear his thoughts were from this impiety.
Man's not impenetrable, can't a ſin
Be frighted into goodneſs? ſure it may:
Skies ſend I live to ſee that happy day.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Witneſs impartial ordinances how
I loath the falſhood of a perjured lover:
Nature commands me to do juſtice, and
It's in my power; ſhe admires him ſtill.
Help me ſome ſhining Spirit to conſult
Your own affairs, and reap the glory on't.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Dear Miſtriſs, I have ſeen a thouſand doomſdays ſince you ſaid I pleaſed you; one word now makes me lighter hearted then a feather; in ſober ſadneſs I ſhall be ſeen no more, if I dye for love: My tears run faſter then Greyhounds for you: a good ſimile is the chiefeſt part of Language: I've read over the Academy of Complements, and pick'd out the beſt rhetorick to wo you; a Parſon may Marry us: be attracted, be attracted.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: The eagerneſs I have of Marrying you,
Makes Moons ſeem twelve-months, every minute hours:
But for my friends good will, I had long ere now
Seal'd to our Wedding.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: You are ſo wiſe, Miſtriſs, that I ſhould be worſe then a Fanatick, to wiſh any thing till you ſay the word.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Theſe are expreſſions fit for ſtrangers, Sir,
Not her that duty tyes to you, ceaſe 'um pray.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p:
The beſt quality of a Sutor, is to be well ſpoken, and pronounce every word with an emphaſis; and I thank my Stars, I have both as ſure as a dye; and if I live, will delight your ears with the
high-flown words of Romances: Amadis de Gaule, and Palmorin de Oliva, ſhall be my every days diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: High properties.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: And I'll delight your ears with ſongs of my own making.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Would you not have me coy?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: 'T would kill me twenty times.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Provide a Prieſt, we'll invite nobody.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Am I above or no? methinks I turn round, and ſee a hundred nooks, and a bag of gold in every one; ſo high and mighty is my rapture: when, Angel, when?

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Be Lord o'th' time your ſelf, when you'll appoint it,
I have chang'd my condition already:
What a tode am I (to ſpeak paſſionately?)

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I bought a Token of my love, and forgot to give it you.

div.stage: Gives her a ſtomacher of Ribonds, and a Love-hood.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: You put your ſelf to charge, I humbly thank you;
Theſe ſhall be my Wedding-Furniture.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Every particle of 'um, I bought them for the ſame purpoſe; to be privately and ſuddenly Married, are the ſymptoms of a fiery and Elegant Lover, you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: You have forc'd my will, meet me at S. Thomas Church,
Ere half an hour's ſpent, I'll be your wife:
Shall I uſe flattery to my deareſt heart?

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I'll hire a Parſon, you prodigious heap of vertues, and meet you ſooner then I would Elyzium delights.

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: Be ſwift, ſweet Sir: for ſince it muſt be ſo,
I'll haſte to Church, and dreſs me as I go.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: I am going to Paradiſe in a down Blanket.

div.stage: Enter four Clowns with a glove lugging.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: You lye you Cur, I ſee it.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Sir, I ſay, I ſee it firſt tho.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: You, guds Waukers, I came when it was welly hot within ſide, ſo I did, you fools.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: So did I, and I'll go carry it to my Lord Lonus.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: So do, it's warm ſtill, and ſo it was, when we all ſee it firſt, Wan't it? then it muſt be his Sons Glove, and he muſt be ſomewhere hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Firſt
sp.p: I'll carry it.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You ſhan't, you whelp, I will.

div.stage: Third takes it up; all take it from him.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: We'll teach you better manners then to ſteal: I dare ſwear it's Litus his glove.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: So I ſay, you may ſee it is a Lords glove mon, by the Ribonds, what doſt talk of that?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: And he's within ſhot.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: I'll carry it to his Father and tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: If you don't ſay we all found it, I'll ſwinge you agood.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: You fool, would you truſt him? I'll cudgel you faith, ſo I will, ha' you no more wit? we'll all carry it together, elſe he'll get the mony to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: You ha' more wit then us all.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Shall's drink when we have done?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: All wheaters, my hony.

div.stage: Enter Beucer leading Sarah in Theles Apparel.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: My humour was fain'd, I'll counterfeit no longer, but be ſerious.

div.stage: Thele enters, and pulls off Sarath's Love-hood: Beucer amazed.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.p: Witchcraft, Witchcraft!

sp.speaker: Thele.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo, 'tis ſo;
Negromancie vaniſh, no Negromancie.

sp.speaker: Winifred.
sp.p: It's ſo indeed, it's ſo my love, my chuck.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: I married her by the name of Thele Moron,
Hers is ſo, and I changed mine to make
Your Marriage firm, and you religious:
She hers from the beginning by deſign.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.p: It's juſt, my Lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Beucer.
sp.l: 'Tis juſt, juſt Maiden, and I free remit
Your ſacred wiſdom that invented it.
Great powers above ordain'd it; and I yeild
I'm rightly ſerv'd, who ſoweth ſhall reap the field.
And now to you dear Miſtriſs, I forgive,
And more commend the plot that makes you live
My deareſt wife, proteſting to Apollo,
This chaſteſt Marriage, chaſtly true to follow,
With pureſt love imbrace, I do repent
What's paſt, and pray our lives hence be content.

div.head: ACT. V.
SCEN. 2.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: MY Lord, between Berania and my Son
You know proceedings, bleſs 'um both together.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: A Devil Devil 'um, he has got my bond, ſo they have, I vow.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: To the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Why, I vow, I think they did it a purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: I mean, ſpeak to the matter.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: So I do, I vow; it's a great matter I ſhould be cheated ſo, ſo it is; but ſhe ſhall have him, if ſhe will, as I live, d'ye ſee? we'll talk by and by, I'll ha' new clothes to the Wedding, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: I'll finiſh quickly to that Gallery there.
Sir, whether ſhould one prize a noble name
And vertuous, or the reſpect of a friend,
If both can't dwell together?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Looſe not the firſt for worlds.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: Was ever any tryed like me?
One of them two I muſt, 'tis your concerns:
I'll dye guiltleſs of your hurt, my Lord:
Pleaſe you to hear me, take the ſaddeſt ſtory
That ere was told, yet ſhort I'll ſtrive to ſpeak it,
It requires privacie.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Madam, we go.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well, we have done a great deal of buſineſs, let me ſee, we have, I vow; well, what then? if my Daughter have Children, I ſhall be a Grand-father, ſo I ſhall.

How d'ye Son-in-law? this is a damnable trouble, ſo it is, till it's
done; you'll make all the haſte you can, d'ye ſee? I vow, I was never half ſo preteritory when I was a Batchelor; if you were Married, it would be over, would it not?

sp.speaker: Loſan.
sp.l: Our meeting, my Lord, tells me 't was ordain'd
You ſhould avoid: 'laſs I can go no further;
I've ſo much breath as ſhall tell you the ſtrangeſt.
Forgive me Skies, ſhall I be falſe, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Tell me why this ſadneſs is upon you.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: I will: turn Rock to hear it, let's be cloſe.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: To kill, or to be kill'd 's the largeſt ſcope
My injuries can give; though all the ſigns
Of Hell and Terror meet me, I'll go on,
And be as famous for my courage in't
As Nero for his tyranny: What boots
A man when dead, to be accounted good?
If his exploits be noted, though they have power
To give an ague at the relation of them,
And make men drop down dead with very fear,
To tell the moſt inhumane bloody murthers
They have committed; yet ſome ſtander by
Adores the Actor for the ſtrangeneſs of 'um.
Dionyſius is as much talkt on, as if
He had chang'd all Cicily to Alms-houſes:
I'm in the cuſtody of ſin, it whirls me
With his byas, and I can't reſiſt it;
As good proceed as draw back and be murthered:
Though I ſhould be ſurpriz'd i'th' midſt o'th' fact,
My name ſhall ſignifie a bloody act.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Whence comes my ruine? he won't ſpeak to me;
What Sorcerer has had to do with him?

div.stage: Enter Petus with his ſword in his hand.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Oh racks of horror! could you finde no other
Subject to work upon, but my deſtruction?
Lidorus, where's the truth your flattering tongue
Would dreſs in pleaſant painted ſkins of Serpents?
Supream Commanders, is my life alone
Odious, that under ſuch a black dark Cloud
You would ſmother all my joys?

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: With grief, my Lord,
I tell you of your faults: love blinded you,
Elſe many a time you might a ſeen him coming
Softly to meet Berania alone;
When you appear'd, he ſlunk away; and ſtill
It is his cuſtom, try, and truſt: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Fawning deluſions, you have took your pride,
To build higher the imaginations of my triumph,
That they the greater downfal may receive:
If I revenge my ſelf, I'm worſt of all.
Tho his diſloyal heart can ſmother up
Such treachery to me, I'll never prove
Guilty of ſo much wickedneſs to him.
But ſtay fond kindeneſs, what, ſhall I incline
To ſpare him his life, that ſeeks to take mine,
I am reduc'd to this untoward end,
Either to looſe my honour, or looſe my friend.
If this my comfort's gone, that to forego,
Makes me ingrateful, and a Traytor too:
He gave it firſt, and who better then he
May borrow that which himſelf lent to me?
In this quandary make thy ſelf a ſheath:
Farewel once Miſtriſs, I muſt bid adieu
To my own ſelf, but firſt of all to you;
When I am dead, that you may know the truth,
My blood ſhall be the pen and writer both:
Though you to others kindneſs could impart,
Yet your name onely's graven within my heart:
If aſk'd, what did this tragedy incur,
You've been the cauſe, but I the Murtherer.
Throw fury on it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: For Heavens ſake, my Lord, tell me the cauſe.

div.stage: Lidorus enters; ſeeing Petus, walks away.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: 'Tis true, ye darts of Pluto nail me here.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Good Sir, ſpeak.
'Tis too much to bear; he has been my friend,
Well, but now he is my foe; and I as juſtly
May make my ſelf his, my ſword ſhall reward it.

div.stage: Loſana and Litus in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: How now, what think you?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: To write an invitation to Lidorus.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Then one or both; Lidorus has the beſt judgement.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: I know't, my Lord, tother's ſooner diſpatcht;
He has no ſkill at all, he dyes, my life for't.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: 'Tis well contriv'd, thanks to your wit and will.

div.stage: Enter Petus with a letter and Page.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Deliver this to Lord Lidorus; flee.

div.stage: Page meets Lidorus, he reads it.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Upon ſuſpition, my Lord, where's the Wiſdom
And ſobriety was moderator
In all your paſſion? quite forgot? tho he
Be frenzied with an Amorous fire, I'll
Not take it as a challenge: Yet conſider,
He's in earneſt; if I don't accept it,
A woman or a coward nick-names me.
In Challenges, we ought more to reflect
On honours ſplendor, then the fight's neglect;
And invitations warlike, ought to be
Anſwer'd with courage, not benignity.
Tell him I ſtay: how clear am I from it?
Sweet is a life retir'd from all affairs
Of State or Court; one ſad miſchance or other
Waits upon Pomp; 't has always emulation
To ſtudy ones own private houſhold-good,
In the ſhort walks of an incloſed Garden;
And there content ſtrikes envy in the boſome.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: My life or his, this treaſon muſt redeem:
Honor then friendſhip ſhould have more eſteem.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Sir.—

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Hold, your villany's too obvious to admit of ceremonious parles.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Charge.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Defend.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: End it.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Diſpatch in juſtice.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: One thing I crave before I dye; tell me
The reaſon of this fight.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: By your life that ſees his laſt period, reſolve
The truth to what I ask.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Elſe Heavens ſhew themſelves my everlaſting enemies.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Haſt not betray'd me? tell your unjuſt dealing.
With Berania, you are both diſhoneſt.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Some miracle of the Gods ſhew my innocence:
Or if I have been guilty, all the torments
In Hell torment me for diſloyalty.
Who blowed this fire in your breſt, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Will't make me kill my ſelf? is it not true?
Loſana told me, and I ſee it too.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: What did you ſee?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: You walk away as ſoon
As entred; 'twas becauſe we were together:
She muſt be alone to entertain your viſits.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Loſona told me, you ſuſpected me
Of being too familiar with your Miſtreſs;
Adviſed me to march off when I beheld
Berania with you, that in time it might
Abate your jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Your coming was upon a match, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: If ſo, let me be match'd with the worſt fury
That ever howl'd in Hell: Loſana bid me
Come to meet her here about ſome buſineſs:
I went when I ſee you, you know the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: I ſmell ſulphur; Loſana told me
What I have ſpoke, and that you were lov'd of her.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Trayterous Loſana, ſhe-Devil, ſhe 'twas, ſhe
Brought me to my grave; ſecure her, I am faint;
The houſe is full of treaſon, uſe your judgement
To puniſh it; I could divulge it now,
But I want breath: I am ſent for, Sir, farewel;
Your innocent ſervant remits you his death:
Once more farewel, and think upon me.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: My Lord, what's this?

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Speak woman, did'ſt thou think
He'd a dyed with a heavy conſcience, and
Conceal'd your ſin to damn him?

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: I'll be tryed with fire, and in my defence
Kiſs glowing ſteel: bring burning coles to me,
I'll keep 'um in my hand till they extinguiſh,
And never cry, to ſhew you I am clear,
Believe me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Did not you and Lidorus 'gree to meet?
He was a coming, but ſeeing me with you, return'd.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: My Siſter bid me come about ſome buſineſs;
I thought not to meet you, and much leſs him.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: It's clear a plot to make us fight; tells him
That I ſuſpected he was too familiar
With Berania: then tells me, that he
Was naught with her indeed; and more, that he
Agreed to meet her, but to walk away
At any time, when he ſee her with me;
Then bids him walk away, when he ſee me,
That it might in time abate my Jealouſie,
And ſo got's all together here unknown
To each other; a caſt a contrived Devilry:
He went away, for fear of my diſpleaſure;
And I thought he went guilty of what was told me;
That we were both innocent, and both ſuſpitious.

sp.speaker: Beran.
sp.p: Litus contrives it, my Maid once or twice ſee 'um together.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Deſperate Loſana, could the Devil invent
To cloak thy damn'd malice with this pretence
Of love to us both?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Lidorus is dead, it's known you kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Juſtice, ſuffer not
A wretch to tread the earth: Villanous woman,
Wert here, I'd gore thy helliſh heart. O Monſter!
Treacherous Monſter; no leſs then thy infernal
Life ſhall ſatisfie me. Dear Lidorus,
How dare I name thee? every noiſe I hear
Crokes horror to me: why, I could not help it,
He can't be brought to life again: I'll dye,
And puniſh my ſelf for ſo damn'd a ſin.
Loſana, Tiger-bitch, to thy breath
My hands inrag'd ſhall give a mournful death:
And for your witch-craft, I will make thee rue it
By juſt revenge, if my lifes price can do it.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Hereabouts 'twas done; Petus is fled.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: He's gone, the King muſt pardon him, or we ſhall ſee him no more: what was it about?

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: They talk of treachy i'th' buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Let's return.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Good morrow my Maſters all, good morrow.

div.stage: Enter King, Guard, and Marus, and Chancellor.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Majeſty, it's I am—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why you know it is againſt our Act that Duels ſhould be fought, the penaltie's death.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: I come not to know rigor, but crave pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: To pardon this, would againſt Juſtice tend.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: Juſtice draws mercy, Sir, at every end.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yea, where the offence is done againſt the will.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: It was my Liege, he did not love to kill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why fought he then?

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.p: To vindicate his right.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: That's got by Law, and not by ſingle might.

sp.speaker: Chancellor.
sp.l: 'T was, Sir, ſo ſudden done, forc'd by a plot,
That ſtrength muſt needs decide, what Law could not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Fathers ſervice, and the Sons deport;
One in our Wars, the tother in our Court,
Tho againſt my Law, command me to aſſwage
For once the penance of my Statutes rage;
But take notice, leſt it ſhould authorize
Others like manner precepts to deſpiſe,
Renew its force; and hence will hardly I
Give him his life that makes another dye.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Your pardon,
But let it teach better things.

div.stage: Litus and Loſana in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: I knew it would not take, Lidorus is dead.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: I wiſh it had been Petus.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Wiſhes nothing avail, our treaſon's divulg'd; and
If we are caught, we ſhall ſoundly ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: My diſgrace is ſo great, I dare not return:
But ſince 'tis ſo, I'll alter our deſign,
And have his life, or it ſhall coſt me mine.

div.stage: Enter Petus in a Night-gown, and Berania.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: A pardon? it were better that I were
Condemn'd to death, by the moſt cruel torture:
To live, is onely to be knawed upon,
And ſuffer lingrings, which ſubtly beguile
Me of my reſt: One blow conſumes them all;
But on my life depends a dearer; and
If I were dead, ſhe'd be expos'd to th' rage
Of bloudy butcheries: I'll be reveng'd.
Dear Lidorus, how ſhall I pacifie
Thy angry Ghoſt! I kill'd thee, and were ſerv'd
But juſt, if thy deathy fingers ſhould
Pull out my timorous heart.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: You ſee, my Lord,
The fruits of too raſh anger.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Would I had,
Dear Madam, ſo ſudden a Burial; let me
Sacrifice my life to aſſwage this fault,
In doubting of your chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: Hold, my Lord, I ſhall dye to ſee you thus;
'T was foul, but now it's over.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Oh that I could come at this demons urchin!
I'd break the charms of Belzebub, and bite
The ſulphry links that keep her; all the flaſhes
Of brimſtone ſhould but heat my purpoſes,
Till with her blood I had made a deadly poyſon
Should kill all that but ſpeak or think upon her:
Where art Air? cover her not, ſhe will infect thee:
Ground ſwallow her up, or throw her to me, that I
May rid the world of luſt and treachery.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: You ſee how things fall out.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: It is reported
You are ſled; Petus beſide himſelf,
Studies to make a ſad example of you.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Are you againſt me too?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Not I, I wiſh
I could but ſee the colour of his heart-blood;
Till then I ſhant be quiet, nor you peel off
Perpetual ſhame.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Does he tear at me thus?

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: I heard him in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: Enough,
I'll do his buſineſs: ſtay here, I have provided.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: I wiſh I had ne'er begun this, I am vext;
I dream of Blood and War: in my condition
Diſtraction banquets: I have entred on it,
And will go on.
But this one way to ſave our lives, go up,

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Here, here, come hither.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We attend your will.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: There's one has done me a great deal of wrong,
'Twill do no good to name it; if you will
Undertake to murder him, you ſhall
Be ſatisfied largely.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: No fear Madam, we can do it.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: I, and we will do it.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Where's the man?

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: Stand in that corner; within a little while he comes to you Gentlemen, be ſure you kill him; I can't deſcribe him by his clothes, but there none comes in a whole year; diſpatch him quickly.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: We'll uſe ſwords to't.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Beſt we have them ready.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Sureſt and ſafeſt, theſe (All draw) will give him a meal he ſhall never diſgeſt, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Go, and don't fail to kill the firſt that comes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We will, faith.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Go to Lord Petus, and tell him you ſaw Loſana go down that lane juſt now; do your arrand well, and here's for you; then out by my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I was a coming to you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I heard you inquire for Madan Loſana,
And I ſee her go down that lane juſt now.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Good Boy.
Now pitty be gone.

div.stage: He goes apace: draws his ſword.
Four Clowns overtake him with clubs, and ſurprize him, taking him for Litus.

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, now we ha' you; nay, go to your Father.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: What mean you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Gentleman us no more then we Gentleman you; for I'faith you ſhall go.

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Hold faſt there: you are an undutiful ſon indeed; we'll Litus you, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: So, I thought we ſhould catch you at laſt.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Stand off, you ruſtick Bores.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hold him faſt; if we let him go, we ſhall all be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Get you home, we have ſearched the woods for you to ſome purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: How dare you Villains?

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.p: Uds waukers, we'll cudgel you, ſo we will, for all you're a Lord.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: There's a good one, ſhall we pleaſe your father or you?

sp.speaker: Third.
sp.p: Swinge him, ſwinge him agood if he won't go; the King man ſet us a work to look you, and gave us leave.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Was ever Noble ſcratch'd with dogs before?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: In with him, in with him to his father; come along, good my Lord Litus, come along, or we'll make you with a murrin.

sp.speaker: Fourth.
sp.p: It muſt be Litus man, and nobody elſe.

div.stage: Litus and Loſana in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: Now Sir, from an abyſs of diſcontent
Three thruſts have built us up ſecurity;
Peace over all thoſe miſts that interpos'd
Between Berania and you are vaniſh'd.
Petus is dead, the Boy came to my Chamber,
And ſee him run to eternal baniſhment:
Them three diſpatcht him, ere one cry could come
Toth' ears of any living. Court your Miſtriſs;
But make devotion to me; I invented
His death, and your felicity.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: Rare Madam!
Seeing there's no lets to my preferment, I'll
Adore your memory, and gratifie
With forty Duckets, them that laid him dead:
Come along Madam, I'll ſee how they ſped.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: They could not finde reſiſtance from him.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.l: I'm raviſh'd with theſe Muſical words,
I'll ſee how they did their buſineſs, and
Content 'um for it.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Well enough, I warrant you.

div.stage: Litus goes to the ſtage, and to the Thieves.
Thieves ſet on him, follow him out and fight.

sp.speaker: Litus.
sp.p: Hold, I am not the man.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He is diſpatcht.

div.stage: They kill him, and ſtop his mouth with an Hankerchaer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Take me for Litus? Oh I fear ſhe's gone.
Ho, ho; Watch, Watch, what's this? what bloudy buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: How came this, do you know, my Lord? I dare not but ask you.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Coming by and ſeeing it, made me cry out.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.l: Alack, he is newly kill'd;
Watch, go purſue the murderers: Alas, my Lord,
This is my Lord Lonus his ſon Litus, for whom
We have ſearch'd ſo long.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: I was ſubdu'd, and carried to his father
Inſtead of him, not twenty minutes ago:
Curſt be the fooliſh meſſengers for't.

div.stage: Enter Watch with one of the Murtherers.

sp.speaker: Murtherer.
sp.p: O be gratious, good my Lord, I'll confeſs all.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: To the Juſtice with him.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: We caught him by himſelf, juſt at the gate.

div.stage: Exeunt all, and carry the body.

sp.speaker: Lonus.
sp.p: Oh my ſon! could I not ſee him ere he dyed?

sp.speaker: Nymph.
sp.l: Now alls fulfill'd, that I
Did with my Siſter propheſie.

p.hi: It is, it is, it is.

sp.speaker: Nymph.
sp.l: Their days ſhall increaſe
In kindneſs, love and peace.

sp.speaker: Nymph.
sp.l: Till the terms of their breath.
Shall be ended by death.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: Now the Seaſon draws nigh,
That we welcome our Bride;
With our Songs Melody,
When all grief's laid aſide.

div.stage: Enter Petus, Marus, Berania and Hacca.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: For thee.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: The Crocodel confeſt it was:
But by kinde providence thoſe Clowns ordain'd
To ſtop me by miſtake, I ſhould ha' periſh'd.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Is my father ſo long a getting my Siſter clear?

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: You have run through tryals.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: This was the moſt horrid,
Take all the ſtory at a fitter time.

div.stage: Enter Occus and Loſana diſtracted in a Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: O come in my Daughter, Loſana doth almoſt deſpair, ſo ſhe does; ſhe is forgiven, ſo ſhe is, and at liberty, I vow, come in.

div.stage: Petus offers to run at her; Berania holds him.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: She is penitent.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: Here they come, I won't go to the Juſtices, I ſhall be burnt, keep me; there's Lidorus his Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: What ails her?

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.p: I'll go to bed; the man in the white cap; the dead man bound under the chin; the great Devils, and the little Devils twitch, and twitch off all the clothes: Look the dead horſe heads chop, and chop in the ſea, and the water all over my chamber: O dear, help, help, a cave in the Wet-wood; the Fryars and the Nuns that are dead, look how they run by me: Now, now again, there's the ſpirit with the withered face ſtands boult upright: d'ye ſee the little beads tumble about? tingle, tingle, tingle, that's the bell in the Monaſtery: Through the grates, the woman in Pautado, is hang'd without her head, for ſaying her prayers: Here comes the Devil like a mourning Gentlewoman with a peak: The Candles burn dim.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what ſhall I do? here's nobody, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.p: In the name of all the Powers be ſilent.

div.stage: She falls down in a ſwound, they recover her; kneeling.

sp.speaker: Loſ.
sp.p: Oh I'm undone! what ails me terror? I'm dead, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Siſter, you have offended grievouſly.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: I am, tho griev'd, not ſham'd to aſk pardon
For that which will defile good lips to utter;
Caus'd by my envy to my Siſter dear:
Envy, damn'd envy, makes me kneeling here.
The Devil and Litus urg'd me with their tongues
To cauſe my Siſters and your death at once:
Which ſinful thought with grief I now repent,
To Litus vile, that I ſhould ſo conſent.
All men, me ſeem'd, did onely well affect
My virtuous Siſter, and my ſelf neglect:
That prompted me to this revengeful ſpight,
Fit to be nam'd in Charon's diſmal night.
I'm juſtly ſerv'd, and Heavens juſt Judge hath brought
My wicked purpoſe to this wicked nought;
And made that evil light on my own head,
With which I hop'd you would be ruined.
Oh pardon me, and I'll henceforward be
Your humble Hand-maid in captivity.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Riſe Loſana, I forgive you
Your baſeſt Treaſon, and henceforward wiſh
That better graces may your Breſt inrich:
Your freeſt freedom, I do not deny,
Do what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Beran.
sp.p: Dear Siſter, ſo do I.

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: I repent all for a preparative
To order and Religon, if I may
Be worthy on't: I humbly beg your leave,
That my devotion may be fitted by
A pilgrimage to the Shrine of Loretto;
By a new favour I may be abſolv'd,
As penitent for all the impious ſtains
Of my bad life.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: I grant you your petition;
Go, if I never ſee you any more,
Labour to expoliate theſe ſins
By earneſt penitence: live holy,
And the everlaſting goodneſs be your guide.

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.l: If we ne'er ſee more, adieu, dear Siſter,
I wiſh you all the ſweeteſt contents of
Your ſtrict and holy being.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: Well, dear hony, God b'w'y, I weep to part, ſo I do: you had beſt take ſome Strong-water with you, I vow, ſo I do, to cheer you up in your long Journey, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Loſana.
sp.l: That ere we ſee if this be the laſt day,
Do you for me, as I for you will pray.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Adieu.

div.stage: Petus takes Berania by the hand.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Now what remains, but after all our fears,
Griefs, ſorrows, troubles, terrors, frights and tears,
We beg.—

div.stage: Enter Meſſenger, gives Petus a Letter.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Make me not miſerable again;
Or is it true? ſpeak, can Lidorus live?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: Read the juſt cauſe of his being ſecret.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.l: Stars,
That of a man have made me an Angel;
Or happier, if't be true; don't tantalize me.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: My Maſter fearing your diſpleaſure, vow'd
I'th' Holy Temple to ſee you beſtow'd
On that fair Lady, or ſee his Winding-ſheet
Laid at his head, ere you ſhould know he liv'd;
But now rejoyces at your welfare.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Where remains the crown of all our ſweetneſs?

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Here, if you are reſolv'd to call it ſo.

sp.speaker: Petus.
sp.p: Forgive me, or puniſh, I am at your mercy.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: Riſe, and be as happy in your Miſtriſs,
As I in ſeeing you: my wounds, though deep,
Were cured on this condition.—

sp.speaker: Berania.
sp.p: Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.l: For offering him a thruſt, my eyes have ſince
I've been recovered, paid the private walls
A thouſand tears.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Let this bright day be worſhip'd:
A univerſal benefit lives with you.
The King has got his thoughts clad all in black
For your ſuppoſed loſs; chang'd to ambition
My ſon, but you to make him glorious.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: It vext me to the heart to hear you were kill'd, ſo it did.

sp.speaker: Lidorus.
sp.p: Don't let me hinder your proceedings, crown your expectation, my felicity.

sp.speaker: Marus.
sp.l: Your hands; I joyn you both, you're man and wife.
The Ceremonies take another time.

sp.speaker: Occus.
sp.p: And ſo ſay I, I vow: but hark, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Hymen.
sp.l: WIth Joy and delight
We'll fill up the night;
That your marriage ſhould be ended,
This dance we intended.
Minerva and the Gods,
When you firſt were at ods,
Did order this ſporting
For your innocent courting.
Then happen what will,
We'll of mirth have our fill:
Your tears were our askers;
Look here come the Maſquers.

div.stage: Deſcend three Goddeſſes, two Gods, one ſinging.

sp.l: Hymen and all the Gods above
That on this Wedding kindly ſmile:
Grant your bleſſings, and your love,
Envy and miſchief to remove,
Peace and plenty all the while.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: We grant it all, it ſhall be ſo:
The Stars our bounty, and our will ſhall know.
Your nuptial pleaſures ſhall abide
So long as love your hearts inflames;
Neer to ceaſe for time or tide,
In joy your days ſhall ſwiftly glide;
With honour we'll ingroſs your names.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: We grant it all, it ſhall be ſo:
The Stars our bounty, and our wills ſhall know.

sp.speaker: Other God.
sp.l: Live like our ſelves, may every hour renew
Triumphs for conſtancy; Garlands for you
Shall be prepared rich, to make you prove
Shining below, as we are bright above:
Till then our Dance and Banquet ſhall diſplay
The pleaſure we have in this happy day.
Muſick. All dance.
